children.subject: Correct.
Thanks a lot, Professor DeNero!
If the student has taken both 16A and 16B, is there a choice a student gets to decide which out of the two they would use to declare CS if they decide to P/NP 70?
No.
Do you have to be taking EECS 16B and CS 70 at the same time to use EECS 16A from a previous semester?

You should contact the instructor for whom you originally took the incomplete and work something out. In some cases, the incomplete will be extended to a future semester. In other cases, you could finish it this semester.
What happens if you're finishing an incomplete from a previous semester in Spring 2020?
Yes. These are degree requirements (not related to the declaration GPA), and all P/NP courses in Spring 2020 will fulfill degree requirements for EECS majors and minors.
Can EECS 16A, EECS 16B still be taken P/NP?
Yes. You can opt for a letter grade and use it. You can also opt for P/NP, request what your letter grade would have been, and use that. It's up to you.
Thank you!
Is it still perfectly fine to opt in for a letter grade and still use it for declaration?
Good question. This policy doesn't cover switching to EECS. The faculty will have to discuss that separately. Sorry to leave you in limbo for a while.

Oh okay!
Any estimate as to when can we expect an update?
It's hard to say. I'll start the process. Next Monday at the earliest, but this could definitely take longer.
In addition, I have the same question but for adding EECS as a double major. This requires a 3.5 average GPA.
Isn't doubling the same as switching to EECS in that it requires at least a 3.3 technical/cumulative/EECS gpa and 1 EECS class per semester at cal?

I asked my counselor and she said that doubling is different since people began flunking classes if they couldn't handle the workload, so they made a requirement of 3.5 total GPA so that they know you can somewhat keep up with the double major requirements.
Thanks so much -- just wanted to remind that Phase 1 enrollment begins in a week and a half on April 13. It would be VERY much appreciated if we had an update on this as soon as possible

Agreed, since we have to take care of not only EECS courses but also other technical courses for this, the fact that this is undecided after nearly 2 weeks of the university announcement deciding P/NP makes me very stressful. Please let us know as soon as possible.
We'll work on it.
Any movement on this?
+1  it's so stressful not knowing whats going on with the new policy
See above. You can P/NP this semester and still change majors.

Thanks for quick update! I did have one question. Do the P/NP classes still count towards the required number of EECS classes needed to transfer? So if a student was finishing their third semester at Cal (needing 3 EECS classes to switch) and had taken 2 EECS classes in previous semesters, would passing a third this semester qualify them to transfer, assuming the gpa in all the other EECS and tech classes met the requirement? Also, does passing non-EECS technical classes affect the calculation of one's technical gpa for the overall 3.3 technical gpa requirement, or is it like the EECS classes where they aren't included?

What about students in COE wishing to switch to EECS?
The current rule for me states that I have to take 4 EECS classes from 61A,61B,EECS 16A, EECS 16B and CS70 and get a 3.3 average in any four. 

If my average in 2 of them satisfies the requirement of 3.3, then can I get a P in my other two classes in Spring 2020 and still be able to declare?

Thanks.
Yes. "P grades for all courses taken in Spring 2020 can be used to fulfill degree requirements that would normally require a letter grade"
Can we take Math 1B p/np for the lower division requirement?
No, sorry.
<md>If I pnp'd ee16a before, is there a way to request what my letter grade would be to declare?</md>
I don't think so. The new policy states, "EECS 16A taken before Spring 2020."
No, sorry.
Can EE16a be used from this semester?
It's the same.

Has the CS appeal process changed or is it still staying the same this semester?

Thanks :D

It appears that it allows you to exclude your 61B grade if you've taken or will take 61A. In this case your Declaration GPA would be calculated with your 61A grade and your CS70 or CS70 replacement grade.
So there is no special provision regarding 61B, just that we can request our letter grade later?
The advisors will do their best on their own, but feel free to contact cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu about how you want your declaration GPA computed, and they'll add that to your application record.

How does one make any of the choices stated above? Will the department automatically optimize the choices a student can make for the highest possible declaration GPA, or will there be an update to the major application itself to reflect these changes
Yep! You just have the choice of excluding your grade for 3.3 purposes if you'd like.
So if I got an A- in 61A and a B in 70, I can declare CS as long as I pass 61b?
I believe you would need a B+ in 61B in that case to make the 3.3
A- in 61A and B in 70 = 3.35 GPA. The P in 61B does not penalize you. So you would be able to declare
So if I take 61B for a letter grade this semester, it's as if nothing's changed for me in terms of declaring?
That has yet to be determined. These policies are not just due to the online format, but also due to the sudden nature of the change and the amount of disruption in people's lives as they moved home.
Will these policies extend to the summer if summer sessions are also online?
wait cant you just use 16A taken previously or 16B taken in the future if you decide to PNP 70?

With policy B, you can receive a Pass in CS70 and utilize another grade instead (one likely not taken this semester and namely 16A and 16B). Hopefully you can consider this portion and not be too stressed out in this time.
If anything, 70 is getting more leeway than 61AB in that we have not 1 but 2 choices for classes that can replace a 70 letter grade this semester. Hopefully that helps you destress a bit.
Yeah, I understand the policy, but you have to wait for one more semester to declare since you must take 16B if you choose P/NP for 70.
I don't think they can take into account how many semesters it will take you to declare considering that this number varies for everyone (some can declare in 2, some declare in 4 etc).

I understand, though. It is too hard to make everyone happy. I wrote this because I'm pretty sure many students (especially, transfer students) may suffer from the same situation as mine. Thank you all.
Yeah but for people who haven't taken the 16 series, it's basically either retake 70 or take letter grade now.
^Anon Gear, dont forget you can do option D too.
@Anon Gear, students have to take the 16 series anyways and D is also an option if you want to P/NP but end up getting a grade good enough for major declaration.
Does that mean that we can receive a NP in CS70 this semester and just have CS61A/B count for our declaration GPA?
@Anon Gear 3, No it's 16 series, not the 61.

It's true that students who haven't taken 16A or 16B previously and decide not to count their 70 grade this semester will have their declaration delayed. We didn't find a better general solution for this scenario. These are very unusual times, and some delays seem inevitable. We've attempted to minimize them.

Responding to a follow-up: If you NP CS70 this semester, you will need to take 70 in a future semester before you can apply to declare. In this case, your future 70 grade would be included in your declaration GPA.
Could the general solution be the current solution to 61a and 61b? IE a pass means you can take the class out of the declaring equation.
No, sorry. This option was discussed and rejected.

Thank you for your reply, professor. As I mentioned above, I know that it is almost impossible to make everyone be satisfied. I also understand that you've already attempted a lot regarding this and I appreciate that so much, anyway. :)

Please see the update. Transfer students may apply even without a CS 70 grade, and those cases will be handled individually, but we expect the most common outcome to be that the application will be denied, in which case the student can apply again once they have a CS 70 grade or substitute.

Thank you so much for your hard work, and I appreciate that.

However, for those who are taking CS70 this Spring2020 semester, this policy is almost forcing us to choose a letter grade. Since we have to declare as soon as possible (especially for the transfer students, we only have 4 semesters to complete the major), this policy doesn't seem to allow us to relieve any stress at all. I understand that CS70 is focusing on mathematical ability, which is way different from CS61A and CS61B, but please please consider this situation once again. Thank you, again.
They get in and the NP doesn't count, since it's replaced with the grade in the future semester per the policy.

So if someone has taken 61a and is taking 61b this semester and receives an NP, and then if they take 61b again and then take 70 and their grades from 61a, 61b repeated, and 70 make the 3.3 cut, do they get into cs or does the NP received in 61b this semester also get included somehow in the gpa requirment
You can request your letter grade any time after final grades have been submitted for the course.
For (D), would the student request to know their letter grade before the end of Spring 2020 or at the time of declaration?
Yes; not using the grade is a choice, not a requirement.
Yes. See the followups above.
Just wanted to confirm. I'm taking CS61B right now. I can still request for letter grade and use that grade for CS declaration right?
We'll discuss — stay tuned.
Yes. See the update above.
Does (B) apply to Math 55 if you're taking it for the Math/CS double major requirements?

In practice, yes. As far as the department is concerned, you can exclude your Spring 2020 grade, and we'll use any other 61B grades you have. The University has a rule that you can't retake a course that you have passed, but I believe this rule is loosely enforced if at all. 

You should probably talk to an advisor before pursuing this option.

Suppose a student takes CS 61B in spring 2020 for a letter grade and receives a passing-but-unimpressive grade (C-range). Can he retake the class in a future semester and replace that spring 2020 grade in the major-GPA calculation?
Yes.
For (B), what if a student receives a P grade for 16A in the previous semester, and a P grade for CS70? Do you still need to take 16B for the declaration?
No.

If we use option D, would the declaration GPA appear anywhere in our transcript in the future? 
For example, if I PNP CS70 but declare it with option D, will anyone in the future (besides the person that declares me) know what corresponding letter grade that was?
Much love for the CS department. This is very generous and much appreciated! Many thanks :)
You can add that to your application, or if you've already applied, you can notify the CS advising team and they'll note it on your record.

This is probably looking too far ahead, but how will we state what policy we choose to use on the CS Major declaration form due by the end of the semester? Namely in my case using 16A grade in place of 70 grade.

No, section B states that EECS16A/16B grades are only used to substitute 70 grades received during spring 2020 semester. "This substitution only applies to Spring 2020 grades in CS 70 of P or letter grades of C- and above."
No.
If I have already taken CS61A and EECS 16A for a letter grade previous semester, am taking CS61B this semester, and have yet to take CS70, can I use my grades from CS61A and EECS 16A to declare CS?

No, these policies don't apply. However, you can talk to the instructor that gave you the incomplete, and they may use these policies to inform what you need to do to complete your incomplete.

Your letter grades in those semesters will still count toward your declaration GPA.
Ok, got it. Thank you for your clarification.

If a student is completing incompletes, 70 and 61b, that were taken in the last semester(fa19) and originally taken for letter grade, do these policies affect the student at all? (i.e. does the student have no choice but to still complete the two classes for letter grade for cs declaration?)
Can we at least get this kind of opportunity through the appeal process?
Having taken Math 53 and 54, I do believe I have the mathematical ability to perform for the CS major. An option like what @atom 2 suggested is worth considering.

Also, another question regarding transfers. If we had the equivalent of Math 54 at our previous institution so we used that to skip 16A or we took 16A last semester but we P/NP, taken 61A last semester, and taking 70 alongside 16B this semester. Are our options to appeal contingent on taking the two P's in both 70 and 16B, take a letter grade in 70, or take a letter grade in 16B? Thanks!

I am in a similar situation where I took Math 54 (at Berkeley) as it was an option for the lower div requirements and so I do not have EECS16A, but I would like to ask the department to really consider allowing the Math 54 grade to be used as a substitute grade similar to EE16A. Having to wait for EE16B to declare could really delay people in our situation.
We'll discuss this situation further. Stay tuned.

As a junior transfer, I'm in a weird position. I took both CS 61B and Math 54 at my community college and CS 61A last Fall. This semester, I'm taking CS 70 to declare. Would it be possible as a transfer student to use my grade in Math 54 in lieu of EECS 16A to declare this semester. Needing to retake CS 70 or take EECS 16B in senior year to declare would definitely be detrimental to transfer students .
Any offering of 16A prior to spring 2020 is fine.

Thanks for the clarification. I wanted to be 100% clear on this because I was told in the CS70 Piazza that I needed to be taking 16B this semester in order to be able to substitute my previous 16A grade in place of 70.

Just to confirm - If we've taken EE16A Spring 2019 and have not taken EE16B and choose to PNP CS70 this semester, could we use our EE16A grade to declare? Or does this only apply for people who took EE16A Fall 2019.
I highly agree that transfer students suffer a serious disadvantage here.
Acknowledged. I'll respond in the thread above regarding this issue once a faculty discussion has concluded.
Thank you sooo much for your consideration, professor. Truly, I appreciate that you're seriously listening to our voices.

I agree that transfer students are in a disadvantageous situation here; having to put another uncertainty during the senior year and not able to get reserved seating for upper-division classes during the senior year. I insist EECS department need to accommodate transfer students by allowing students to use their Math54 and Math55 grades from their CC instead of using EE16B to declare in the senior year.
Yes.

If someone choose to take letter grade for 61b instead of P/NP. but it turns out they got a very bad grade (like, say C+, which is passing). Can they exclude 61B letter grade in this case?

(So if they got 3.3GPA for both CS70 and CS61A, will they be able to declare? )
Yes.

If I took CS 61a and EE 16a last semester, and am currently taking CS 61B and CS 70 this semester, as per these rules, can I use 16a to substitute for 70 and exclude 61b from my declaration GPA? I.e. could I just use 16a and 61a to declare?

Also B) Students may choose to substitute for their Spring 2020 grade in CS 70 using one of (i) their grade in EECS 16A taken before Spring 2020, (ii) their grade in EECS 16B (taken any time), or (iii) their grade in CS 70 retaken in a future semester. This substitution only applies to Spring 2020 grades in CS 70 of P or letter grades of C- and above

does this mean that if I am taking 16B too this semester I can choose either 70 or 16B to be used as my letter grade to declare?

First question: no. You must complete all declaration prerequisites (61A, 61B, 70) before you can declare. Grades in all of these courses will count unless they are excluded or substituted according to the policy.

Second question: yes. You could use either your 70 or 16B grade in place of your 70 grade this semester.

I'm confused so it says: Students may choose to exclude their Spring 2020 grades in CS 61A, CS 61B, and/or CS 47B from their declaration GPA as long as their declaration GPA includes a grade from at least one of CS 61A, CS 61B, or CS 47B.

So does that mean that if I've taken 61A and 61B in previous semesters and got A's then I can already declare?
That's accurate.

For my specific case, I'm a little confused. Having taken CS61A and EECS 16A already in my Berkeley career, and currently taking CS61B and CS70 in this overwhelming Spring 2020 Semester, could I theoretically opt to replace my 70 grade with EE16A, and have my 61B grade removed from GPA declaration purposes. I know that myself and many others are in a similar situation, and I'm asking because in this case, I would be declaring the CS major with CS61A and my CS70 replacement: EE16A, neither of which I am taking this semester. 
Is this accurate? I just want to make sure I have that correct. Thanks!
We'll discuss. Stay tuned.
So if I P/NP both 16B and 70 this semester then I would have to request to use my 70 grade that I would've gotten to declare assuming I haven't taken 16A? I cannot request my 16B grade?
You seem to have pointed to a slightly different part also, but Professor, DeNero said he would discuss it with other faculties, so let's wait and see, dude. :)
Acknowledged. I'm sorry that it's difficult to focus on classes. It is for us faculty as well.

Thank you so much for pointing this out. I am a sophomore who needs to declare ASAP, and I was disappointed as I have not taken 16a/b yet. I cannot afford to take summer classes, so worst come to worst, this policy would delay my graduation and mess up my schedule. I was stressed this past 2 weeks as my hometown was hit hard by COVID-19, and my financial situation worsened(my father's business is not doing well). Thank you faculty members for taking in different factors so that the policy would help as many students as possible.

<md>Under the current policy, a freshman taking 61b and 70 together and who took ee16a and 61a last semester can declare with ease. I don't think 61a and ee16a are representative of the knowledge of the 61 series and 70, so I'm not sure why 70 cannot have the same policy as the other classes. This policy does not remove any stress at all, and basically puts a choice of either taking a letter grade or further delay declaration, and given the COVID-19 outbreak is not likely to end any time soon, who is to say that taking it again or ee16a/ee16b will yield a better outcome. Add in financial insecurity, and I find that the current policy disadvantages 70 students who have not taken 16a/b greatly. I find the appeal to the comparison between current policy that P's are C-'s and the new policy to be quite disingenuous as the current policy was made in mind without a global pandemic that is projected to cause 200,000 or more deaths in the US. I'm also saying this without a bias towards self interest as I simply need a C plus to declare. Even with my privileged personal circumstances, I am finding it extremely difficult to focus on classes with my family experiencing financial insecurity. I am sure many students have it much worse than me. I think it's unfair for students who did not take ee16a/16b yet and for sophomores who were careful in managing their difficulty of their schedule to declare. I urge the EECS department to reconsider, and err on the side of students' interests because of a once-in-a-lifetime pandemic.</md>
I don't anticipate a change in enrollment policy.

Hi! I'm planning on doing an EECS double and am wondering about class sign-ups for the following semester, given that this change to policy may affect students' plans for fall 2020 classes if they determine they might have to delay their declaration. Any foresight (from faculty or student) would be appreciated!

A decision by COE is yet to be finalized. COE has maintained the FAQs here:

The policy hasn't changed. The fact that you can apply to declare without a CS 70 grade is new. I would only recommend this option if you believe that there is clear evidence in your transcript of mathematical maturity, for example from math courses taken at Berkeley.

Afaik, changing to EECS only has a requirement of having an EECS gpa of 3.3 or above. If two of your classes satisfy the requirement cap for EECS gpa, then the other technical class should not matter imo.
thanks, leaving unresolved for instructor confirmation
To the person who keeps resolving this thread, DON'T DO IT.
You are allowed to P/NP technical courses, and then those courses would not contribute to your technical GPA.

I checked the new update for CoE students who want to change major to EECS. Are we able to PNP technical courses other than EECS courses and still change major? (Let's say this is my second semester at Cal and I have 2 EECS letter grades above 3.3 and one other technical course. Is it available to change major to EECS with 3 letter grades at the end of this semester - two EECS course and 1 other technical?)
Yes.

Thank you for the reply professor and consideration. However, many of us, L&S students, have taken Math 54 in place of EE16A, since the CS department approved Math 54 to be a substitute for EE16A. Had such substitute policy not been established, we, as people trying to declare as CS majors, would not have taken Math 54 instead of EE16A. I would earnestly entreat you to consider that a lot of us are sophomores, juniors, and transfer students who need declaration as soon as possible in order to embark on a career journey to apply our class lessons in a real world setting. Nevertheless, our career journey is about to be delayed due to the extenuating circumstance that we have no control over. Hence, may I please ask if our faculties can reconsider Math 54 being used in place of EE16A given that it was an officially approved course to substitute EE16A?

Thank you for your consideration.

Hello Professor, 

Many transfer students have used a Math 54 substitute in place of EECS 16A. As a result, they are taking EECS 16B alongside CS 70 this semester. I believe that this policy disadvantages junior transfer students since they have a limited time in completing their coursework. Thank you for your consideration.

May I please ask if the new update that was released today morning is final, such that Math 54 is not available to be used in  replacement for EE 16A? 

Thank you.

Depends on your scenario. If you're taking 70 this semester as well, then your declaration grade would be based on 61a and 70 grade (or 70 substitute). If you aren't taking 70 this semester, then it's based on the 61a grade and 70 grade, and there are no substitutes for 70.
In either case, the 61a grade isn't counted twice, correct?
It would not be counted twice, no.

Just to make sure: If I took 61a last semester and choose to exclude 61b this semester as described in A, the gpa taken into consideration would only be the average of 70(or 70's substitute) and 61a (i.e. 61b isn't "replaced" by 61a, it's just dropped).
I have this question too. When do we request for what our letter grade would have been for calculating the GPA requirement? Thank you!

Just to clarify: for double major in EECS, if I completed cs61a last semester, and taking 61b this semester. I can pnp the 61b, and the department will use the "pseudo grade" for declaring the second major once I submit the forms?Also, how do I get a "pseudo grade", do I need to email my instructor to request it?
That's not determined in advance. The faculty member who evaluates appeals would look at your entire transcript.

" A student receives a P in both CS 61A and 61B in Spring 2020; the student has two options: appeal to declare the major, in which case other grades will be considered, or use provision D below."

What other grades would be considered?
I don't understand why this keeps being marked resolved when this question has not been answered.

Thank you so much for all the hard work to make these changes as fair as possible. 

However, I am confused behind the reasoning to not have Math 54 as an acceptable replacement for EE16A. For L&S students, 54 is considered a viable replacement for EE16A in terms of degree requirements. 

Personally, I know that there are many students in CS70 who opted to take 54 instead of 16A and feel that they are at a disadvantage because they chose to take 54. Can someone please shed some light as to why this decision was made?

No. You may take CS70 for P/NP for the CS minor and do not need to substitute the grade. You must earn a P for it to count for the minor. 

Any classes taken in Spring 2020 for the CS minor may be taken P/NP and must be passed.

How does this grading policy affect declaring the CS Minor? If we are completing CS 70 for declaring the minor this semester (the last requirement needed), do we need to take it for a letter grade? Or can we PNP? Replace it with EE 16B? Thanks for the help.

<md>
+1, The omission of math 54 is jarring.
</md>

As an already-declared objective observer, I would have to agree that the decision not to include Math 54 seems strange. If the point of having EE 16A be a valid substitute for CS 70 is so that there is some measure of factoring "mathematical maturity" into the GPA calculation (as said above), then it seems odd that performing well in Math 54 is not considered a sufficient demonstration of this "mathematical maturity." Having taken both, I'd argue that Math 54 tested one's math ability far more than 16A.
Are there any updates regarding this thread? Or at least, may I ask if the faculties can at least shed lights on the reason why Math 54 could not be included for the replacement while EE16A is?

Adding onto the plea for Math 54 to be acknowledged, here is an important perspective (keep in mind, that I only care about my own grade and I'm simply stating this situation so the unfair gravity of the situation is acknowledged): when my friend and I entered CS70, we both needed the same grade, a B-, in CS70 to declare L&S CS. The only difference is that they took EE16A and I took Math 54. Now, we have had similar grades on both midterms but because they took EE16A instead, they only need 9 points on MT3 to get a C- and declare while I need 39 points (out of 65) to get a B- and declare. This is a huge difference. Not only in the bar to declare but student stress during this already troubling time.

And for what?

Why are we punishing students for taking Math 54 rather than EE16A prior to Covid19 when they count for the exact same requirement? How were we supposed to know at that time, before Covid19, that we should've picked one or the other when the department said it didn't matter?

It is said that this EE16A policy will help students to not focus too much on their grades and focus on learning the material but for students who took Math 54, our stress levels have been through the roof and we have been beat down ever since it was put in place despite the fact that we have worked just as hard and learned just as much as the EE16A people in terms of proofs and linear algebra and we shouldn't be punished for following guidelines and choosing 1 of the 2 courses which fulfill the exact same requirement. 

Please, consider allowing Math 54 to hold the same as EE16A does in helping students to stress less about their grades.
Please don't mark this as Resolved, because I really need a confirmation.

Is it confirmed that I can retake 70 in the future semester even if I get a P this semester? Or is this still under discussion? If I don't think I can get a high-enough grade in 70 this semester to declare, can I retake it without failing or not passing?

+1 Please don't. We really need information or any possible-reconsideration on Math 54 being a replacement for EE16A given that we have taken this course as it was officially approved by the school. Be safe all!
I would really appreciate it if people would stop resolving follow-ups that clearly don’t have a response yet. Thank you.

Just to be clear, the update on math/cs double majors taking Math 55 only applies to policy 2b, not 2d?

In other words, if I receive a P in Math 55 and have not taken EE16A, I cannot request to know what letter grade I would have received and use this letter grade in my declaration GPA. I would have to take both EE16A and 16B to declare.

Are these new policies official & guaranteed, or are they still at all tentative/ awaiting university approval?

I just want to confirm that this policy (courses taken P/NP count towards degree requirements) also covers courses taken during study abroad that have been pre-approved as equivalent.

For example, I am currently taking a course at the University of Edinburgh that is approved for CS 168. Taking this course P/NP would be fine?
This maybe really dumb...but I took EE 16A in Spring 2019 and its name changed to EECS 16A from last semester onwards...but it counts as the same right?
The CS department will have that grade on file.

I emailed cs advising and they said under "Alternative/UCB course" field of CS 70, just mention "Please use grade memo"

Hope that helps!
What if I'm taking math 55 PNP, can I ask my professor to keep my grade on file and send it to you?
For option D, how do we go about showing the CS department what grade we would've gotten?

history.content:
The EECS department faculty have approved two policy changes related to degree programs administered by the department. Both are designed so that there is no benefit to electing a letter grade for any course in Spring 2020 with respect to declaration or graduation. You can keep the default grading option of P/NP in all of your courses without compromising your graduation plans or reducing your chances of declaring the L&S CS major.

1) P grades for all courses taken in Spring 2020 can be used to fulfill degree requirements that would normally require a letter grade for the following:

- Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) Major
- Letters & Sciences Computer Science (L&S CS) Major
- Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) Minor
- Computer Science (CS) Minor
- Electronic Intelligent Systems (EIS) Minor


2) Regarding the GPA used to evaluate applications to the L&S Computer Science major (below called the "declaration GPA"), which normally includes all grades from CS 61A, CS 61B (or CS 47B), and CS 70 (or CS 47F) that are taken at UC Berkeley:

A) Students may choose to exclude their Spring 2020 grades in CS 61A, CS 61B, and/or CS 47B from their declaration GPA as long as their declaration GPA includes a grade from at least one of CS 61A, CS 61B, or CS 47B.

Examples:

i) A student receives a P in CS 61A in Spring 2020 and takes CS 61B and CS 70 in future semesters; the student may choose to exclude the CS 61A grade and use only grades from CS 61B and CS 70.

ii) A student receives an NP in CS 61A in Spring 2020 and takes all three courses in future semesters; the student may choose to exclude the NP in CS 61A and use only grades from CS 61A, 61B, and 70 in future semesters.

iii) A student receives a P in both CS 61A and 61B in Spring 2020; the student has two options: appeal to declare the major, in which case other grades will be considered, or use provision D below.


B) Students may choose to substitute for their Spring 2020 grade in CS 70 using one of (i) their grade in EECS 16A taken before Spring 2020, (ii) their grade in EECS 16B (taken any time), or (iii) their grade in CS 70 retaken in a future semester. This substitution only applies to Spring 2020 grades in CS 70 of P or letter grades of C- and above.

Examples:

i) A student receives an A in EECS 16A in Fall 2019 and a P in CS 70 in Spring 2020; the student may choose to substitute the A for the P in their declaration GPA.

ii) A student receives a P in CS 70 in Spring 2020 but has not taken EECS 16A; the student may choose to take either EECS 16B or retake CS 70 in a future semester and substitute either of those grades for their P in their declaration GPA.

iii) A student receives a P in CS 70 and a P in EECS 16B in Spring 2020 and has never taken EECS 16A; the student should appeal to declare the major, and other grades will be considered.


C) Students may choose to exclude their Spring 2020 grade in CS 70 of NP, F, D-, D, or D+ from their declaration GPA.

Example:

i) A student receives an NP in CS 70 in Spring 2020 and then retakes CS 70 in a future semester; the student may choose to exclude the NP from their declaration GPA.


D) Students who receive a grade of P in any of CS 61A, CS 61B, or CS 70 in Spring 2020 may request to know what letter grade they would have received had they elected letter grading, and they may choose to use this letter grade in place of the P in their declaration GPA.

Example:

i) A student receives a P in CS 70; they request to know what letter grade they would have received, and the instructor says that they would have received an A. They may include this A in their declaration GPA in place of the P.

Students can book an appointment with a CS Major advisor or email cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu to discuss their individual cases and determine their next steps toward completing the prerequisites and declaring L&S Computer Science.

Update 4/7 10am

- Students must complete (with a passing grade) all major prerequisite courses (61A, 61B, 70 or equivalent) to apply to the L&S CS major. (This information isn't new, but some students were confused; this policy only affects the declaration GPA calculation, not the set of required courses.)
- Transfer students who have completed all major prerequisite courses (61A, 61B, 70 or equivalent) but do not have all letter grades needed to declare (e.g., they have no letter grade in CS 70 or any allowed substitute) may appeal to declare in Spring 2020, and the department will consider their other coursework. In most cases, we expect that the appeal will be denied, in which case the student should apply to declare again in a future semester once they have a full set of letter grades.
- Math/CS double major students taking Math 55 in Spring 2020 who receive either a P or a letter grade of C- or better may substitute for their Math 55 grade in any of the ways described in policy 2B above. Retaking Math 55 in a future semester is not an allowed substitute; take EECS 16B or CS 70 instead.
- Within the College of Engineering, change-of-major applicants may choose whether or not to include each Spring 2020 grade in their EECS GPA. Students need at least two letter grades in EECS courses to apply for a change of major.

In most cases, we expect that the appeal will be denied, in which case the student should apply to declare again in a future semester once they have a full set of letter grades. - Math/CS double major students taking Math 55 in Spring 2020 who receive either a P or a letter grade of C- or better may substitute for their Math 55 grade in any of the ways described in policy 2B above. Retaking Math 55 in a future semester is not an allowed substitute; take EECS 16B or CS 70 instead. - Within the College of Engineering, change-of-major applicants may choose whether or not to include each Spring 2020 grade in their EECS GPA. Students need at least two letter grades in EECS courses to apply for a change of major. #pin
